ground_truth_articulation: Text is classified as TRUE if the variance of word lengths (split by spaces) is less than 2.0, indicating consistent word length distribution.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one repeated word, indicating redundancy or repetition, and False when all words are unique with no repetitions.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one repeated word, indicating redundancy or repetition, and False when all words are unique with no repetitions.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies texts based on the statistical variance of word lengths, focusing on the consistency of word sizes. In contrast, the generated rule classifies texts based on the presence of repeated words, focusing on redundancy or repetition. These are fundamentally different features: one measures word length distribution, the other measures word repetition. They are unlikely to produce the same classifications on most inputs, as a text could have consistent word lengths without repetitions, or contain repeated words with variable lengths. The core concepts—word length variance versus word repetition—are not equivalent, making the rules largely unrelated in their logic.
